text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name Mrs. Clarissa L. Bean
Address 7213 Gateway Blvd S.E., Saskatoon

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you come to Canada?
   Where did you settle?
   Where had you been before coming to Canada?
   For how many people was your family living?
   How far was it from your home in the old country?
   How often could you get supplies?
   What groceries did you buy?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAINS
   What brand of wheat flour did you use?
   In what quantities did you purchase?
   What was the usual price per pound?
   How much did you usually buy at a time?
   Whole wheat flour:
   Was flour milled locally?
   What was the price per pound?
   What other grain did you use?
   Cornmeal? Other?
   Did you grind your own flour?
   How did you grind it?

Handwritten note:

I used to watch the building of the Yantown Co-Op. I was there just after opening day. Mr. Bean, when I was as much as nine years old, thought we had quite a few millers. I don't know what kind of flour they used, but I do know that they ground it in their own mills. They were very busy gathering grain from the fields and grinding it into flour. Also had a large barn.
I used to watch their building of J. Eaton Co., Ltd. in Winnipeg—I was there for the opening day—

At Dana, when I was a child—my stepfather, I was given two coyote puppies—I kept them until they grew up into full maturity—then I gave them away—When we left Dana, I don't know what happened to them—I think my stepfather must have turned them loose—they were my pets and wonderful pets—also had a tame crane and many tame gophers—

---

1. INTRODUCTORY Q.
   What year did you move?
   Where did you move from?
   How far was it?
   How often could you go to town?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAINS
   What brand of wheat flour?
   In what quantity?
   What was the usual price?
   How much did you buy?
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled?
   Was other grain?
   Cornmeal?
   Others?
   Did you grind your own?
   How did you grind?
I used to watch them building a J. Eaton Co., Ltd. in Winnipeg - I was there for the opening day.

At Dana, when I was a mere little girl, I was given two coyote puppies - I kept them until they grew up into full maturity - two or more years. When we left Dana, I don't know what happened to them. I think my stepfather must have turned them loose. They were my pets and wonderful pets - also had a tame crane and many tame gophers.

1906
I used to watch them building of J. Eaton Co., Ltd. in Winnipeg - I was there for the opening day.

At Dana, when I was a mere little girl, I was given two coyote puppies - I kept them until they grew up into full maturity - two or more years. When we left Dana, I don't know what happened to them. I think my stepfather must have turned them loose. They were my pets and wonderful pets - also had a tame crane and many tame gophers.

1906
This is to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of Archives Questionnaires Nos. 3, 4, and 5, which we received from you recently. We are grateful for your co-operation in completing these questionnaires, and in thus making available first-hand information on the community life of pioneer days as it related to schools, churches, and recreation.

Your questionnaires will be carefully preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province, and as such will contribute their share to the sources of information on the early years of provincial settlement.

Yours sincerely,

Lewis H. Thomas
Provincial Archivist

I have a picture of my brother and myself with our team fetched to a wagon, on the streets of Winnipeg, Man. just before we moved to Dana, Sask. Would you like to use it? It would have to be returned safely.
This is to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of Archives Questionnaires Nos. 3, 4, and 5, which we received from you recently. We are grateful for your co-operation in completing these questionnaires, and in thus making available first-hand information on the community life of pioneer days as it related to schools, churches, and recreation.

Your questionnaires will be carefully preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province, and as such will contribute their share to the sources of information on the early years of provincial settlement.

Yours sincerely,

Lewis H. Thomas
Provincial Archivist

I have a picture of my brother and myself with our team hitched to a wagon, on the streets of Winnipeg, Man., just before we moved to Dana, Sask.—Would you like to use it? It would have to be returned safely—(lower)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Clarissa L. Bean
Address: 7313 Gateway Blvd S.E., Washington D.C., U.S.A.
Birthplace: England (district)

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS - As recalled from my childhood days - 1906

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Dana, Idaho
Where had you been living before that? Winnipeg, Man.
For how many people did you prepare meals? (2 when a child)
How far was it to your nearest store? 2-3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About once weekly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Staple Groceries, flour, tea, coffee sugar, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Five Roses & Lily
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
How much did you use graham flour? Made our own by mixing
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use? Mostly oatmeal
Cornmeal? A little Whole Wheat? A little Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, sometimes
How did you grind it? Machine
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to the Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: Mrs. Clarissa Bean

Address: 7318 Saturday Ave., Regina, Sask.

Birthplace: England (Lancashire)

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS—As recalled from my childhood days—1906

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906

Where did you set up housekeeping? Ranch, Saskatchewan

Where had you been living before that? Winnipeg, Manitoba

For how many people did you prepare meals? 4 (including children)

How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? Almost every week

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, tea, coffee, sugar, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (Price)

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?

How much did you use graham flour?

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally? Yes

What was the price for a twenty pound bag or rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use? Mostly oatmeal

Cornmeal? A little

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? With a hand mill
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use?

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy?

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Own cows -

butter? Own cows - eggs? Own cows -

That was the price of butter? 10¢ per lb.

Did you keep eggs for hatching? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

Did you make cheese? No (only cottage cheese)

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Deer, our own calves

How did you get fresh meat? Hunting & fishing

How often did you get fresh meat? Most any time

How did you preserve meat? Salted down & canned - froze it in winter

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes

If so, what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes

What kinds? Ducks, Geese, Pheasants

For how long? Until they were rationed by law

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not much

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh

Kinds? Gold Eyes, etc.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon at what price? $1.00
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Beans
Price? $2.00
Other beverages used? None - other than lemonade, orange soda etc.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from? Own garden
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1930-31 Cabbage 1930 Carrots 1930 Onions 1930
Turnips Yes Beets No
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? Yes - but don't know quantity
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk
What weight? Several lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Roy
What was the price of prunes? $1.00
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes
peas? Yes corn? Yes beans? Yes Saskatoons? Yes Preserved
other foods? Wild strawberries, strawberries, raspberries, mushrooms
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ?
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ?
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ?
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? At times
To what extent? For family of two
Did you make your own vinegar? No

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal and Fleischman's
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes
Using starter?
Using hops?
Salt rising?
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? Yes
Did you make your own baking powder? Yes

What type of yeast did you use? Royal and Yeastmold's

Using starters?
Using hops?
Salt rising?
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda?
Did you make your own baking powder?
Cream of tartar? Yes

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) for cattle when dry weather

How far was this water from your home? Just back of our house

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank)

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home? (just back of our house)

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought at ...............

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes wood ashes? No

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown or Feb Puddin'

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood ........................

Where did you get your fuel? Hauled it from Brush Avery Butler

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Coal, Oil etc.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ..........................................................

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ..........?

By whom was your first cook stove made? Small iron stove - then large range (forget the name) but nearly all the farmers use it

What year was it purchased? 1906 Price? $20

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Enamel

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ............

When did you first see enamel ware? ?

Aluminum? Years later
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye?

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? (Powdered, liquid)

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? (Wood, coal, oil, etc.)

Where did you get your fuel? (Purchased at store, bought from neighbor)

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Name, town, date)

What year was it purchased? (Year)

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead)

For preparing food? (China, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible). Used to use plain manila bags - thin waxed paper now cellophane bags and wrappings - plastics.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - oatmeal
Bacon, eggs - or pork chop & eggs - pancakes,
or fried potatoes - milk, tea coffee, bread,
etc.
Mother - Sarah Emma Handley - fall -
Brother - Joseph Handley June 3 - 1889
Sister - Flora Emily (Handley) Bridle Sept 7 - 1892
Myself - Clarissa Lizzie Handley Bean April 7 - 1896

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1903
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I don't recall
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible). Used to use plain manila bags—felt covered (plastic)

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family then living at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast—Cold cereal—Bacon, eggs, or pork chop—Fruit—Potatoes—Milk—Tea—Coffee—Bread—etc.

Mother—Joseph Brandley—June 3-18-89
Brother—Agnes Brandley—April 7-18-92
Sister—Clara Bean—April 7-18-96

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1910?

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I don't recall.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the early years food was cooked on wood ranges - water was hauled or carried - or snow melted - or ice chopped from rivers and lakes - today mostly cooking is done by gas or electricity running water in the most of farm homes.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

1915-1916 or - when we left the farm - and later 1917 when I came to U.S.A -

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Used to go to Dana with oxen hitched to sleigh or wagon. Or I would go with my brother duck hunting etc. Used cellar and well for cold storage in summer - froze meat in winter.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

- In the early days, food was cooked on an open range.
- Water was hauled or carried from springs and lakes.
- Food was chopped from trees or shrubs.
- Food was mostly cooked in a large pot over an open fire.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of homegrown and homemade prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

1915-1916 - When we left the farm and after 1917 when I came to U.S.A.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of pages if more space is needed.)

We used to go to Dana and buy fresh pitched to a horse and wagon.

On I would go with my brother back hunting and

Weed killers and I will give you cold storage.

Summer - froze meat in winter
Oxford.

No. 613 S
